'''James "Stump" Johnson''' (January 17, 1902 – December 5, 1969)<ref name="Dead">[http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1960.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com - accessed March 2010]</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[pianist]] and [[singing|singer]] from [[St. Louis]].

==Biography==
James "Stump" Johnson was the brother of Jesse Johnson, "a prominent black business man," who around 1909<ref name="stump">{{cite AV media notes
| title       = James "Stump" Johnson 1929-1964
| titlelink   = 
| others    = James "Stump" Johnson
| year        = 1993
| chapter  = 
| url         = 
| first       = Rijn
| last        = Guido van
| authorlink  =
| coauthors   = 
| pages       = 2
| type      = CD booklet
| publisher   = [[Document Records|Document]]
| id = 
| location    = 
}}</ref> had moved the family from [[Clarksville, Tennessee]], to St. Louis, where he ran a music store and was a promoter.<ref>{{cite book  | last = Townsend  | first = Henry  | authorlink = Henry Townsend (musician)  |author2=Bill Greensmith  | title = A blues life  | publisher = U of Illinois P  | year = 1999  | page = 116 n.5  | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=HaeDzHuXhooC&pg=PA116  | isbn = 978-0-252-02526-6}}</ref> James, a self-taught piano player,<ref>{{cite book  | last = Cunningham  | first = Lyn Driggs  |author2=Jimmy Jones  | title = Sweet, hot, and blue: St. Louis' musical heritage  | publisher = McFarland  | year = 1989  | page = 99  | isbn = 978-0-89950-302-8}}</ref> made a career playing the city's brothels.<ref name="screening">{{cite book  | last = Oliver  | first = Paul  | title = Screening the blues: aspects of the blues tradition  | publisher = Da Capo Press  | year = 1989  | page = 171  | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=CrBNQjQzcwUC&pg=PA171  | isbn = 978-0-306-80344-4}}</ref> He had an instant hit with the "whorehouse tune"<ref name="stump"/> "[[The Duck's Yas-Yas-Yas]]," "a popular St. Louis party song."<ref>{{cite book  | last = Hentoff  | first = Nat  | authorlink = Nat Hentoff  |author2=Albert J. McCarthy  | title = Jazz: New Perspectives on the History of Jazz by Twelve of the World's Foremost Jazz Critics and Scholars  | publisher = Da Capo Press  | year = 1975  | page = 219  | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=WeHRWNo7p7oC&pg=PA219  | isbn = 978-0-306-80002-3}}</ref> The song's title is explained by quoting the lyrics more fully: "Shake your shoulders, shake 'em fast, if you can't shake your shoulders, shake your yas-yas-yas."<ref name="stump"/>

He made a number of other recordings (some mildly pornographic) under various pseudonyms.<ref>{{cite book  | last = Oliver  | first = Paul  | title = Conversation with the blues  | publisher = Cambridge UP  | year = 1997  | page = 190  | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=hw9n90DDu2MC&pg=PA190  | isbn = 978-0-521-59181-2}}</ref> One of the more obscene tunes was a version of "Steady Grinding", which he recorded with [[Dorothea Trowbridge]] on August 2, 1933;<ref>{{cite book  | last = Oliver
  | first = Paul  | title = Screening the blues: aspects of the blues tradition  | publisher = Da Capo Press  | year = 1989  | page = 272 n.29  | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=CrBNQjQzcwUC&pg=PA272  | isbn = 978-0-306-80344-4}}</ref> the song has the "defiant, sexually aggressive lyrics" early blueswomen were noted for,<ref name="winsby">{{cite book|last1=Winsby|first1=Meghan|last2=Fairweather|first2=Abrol|editor=Jesse R. Steinberg|others=Abrol Fairweather|title=Blues - Philosophy for Everyone: Thinking Deep About Feeling Low|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=tnqoFDqW-mYC&pg=PA160|year=2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780470656808|pages=153–75|chapter='The Blue Light Was My Baby And The Red Light Was My Mind': Religion and Gender in the Blues}}</ref> "grind" being slang for copulating.<ref>{{cite book|last=Calt|first=Stephen|title=Barrelhouse Words: A Blues Dialect Dictionary|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=plD_T3xdJ5AC&pg=PA275|year=2009|publisher=U of Illinois P|isbn=9780252033476|page=275}}</ref>
